intro: Comparettia corydaloides, commonly known as the orchid of the Andes, is a member of the Orchidaceae family and is native to South America. It is a terrestrial orchid characterized by its erect, branching stems and clusters of fragrant, showy flowers. The plant typically grows in humid, shaded environments, often in cloud forests at high altitudes. Its flowers are usually yellow or greenish-yellow with a distinctive, elongated lip. Comparettia corydaloides is valued for its ornamental appeal and is cultivated for its unique floral structure and fragrance.
